content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- The first Nasdaq-listed stock to resume trading, Atlantic American Corp. AAME, +3.13% rose 0.5% as the exchange tested trading following an outage. Equity trading in Nasdaq-listed securities is slated to resume at approximately 3:25 p.m. Eastern time, a delay from an earlier resumption time of 3:10 p.m. AAME is functioning as a test stock.
title: Atlantic American up as Nasdaq prepares to reopen

content: Eloyalty quarterly loss widens (8:42 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Eloyalty Corp. ELOY after Thursday's closing bell reported a second quarter net loss of $2.9 million, or 52 cents a share, vs. a net loss of $432,000, or 13 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue at the Lake Forest, Ill.-based management consulting firm rose to $19.6 million from $18.2 million last year. The company forecast third-quarter revenue in the range of $20 million to $22 million. Cosi quarterly loss widens (8:07 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Cosi Inc. COSI after Thursday's closing bell reported a second-quarter net loss of $1.9 million, or 6 cents a share, vs. a net loss of $1.6 million, or 5 cents a share, in the year-ago period. On a pro forma basis, the company reported a per-share loss of 2 cents compared with 4 cents last year. Revenue at the Deerfield, Ill.-based restaurant chain rose to $30.6 million from $29 million a year ago. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call expected a quarterly loss of 4 cents on revenue of $30.7 million. Cosi now expects a 2005 loss of 11 cents a share, compared with its earlier loss estimate of 14 cents to 18 cents a share. It expects full-year same-store sales growth between 7% and 9%. Cosi had previously forecast same-store sales to rise 4% to 5% in 2005. Fedders warns of 2Q loss, lower rev; delays filing 10-Q (6:46 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Air treatment products maker Fedders Corp. FJC, -9.74% said Thursday evening that it expects to swing to a second-quarter loss of $600,000 and sees sales decreasing 29% to $127 million compared with last year. The company attributed the sales decline to increased inventory of air conditioners that were carried over from 2004 because of cooler-than-normal weather. It expects gross margin to increase to 20% from 16.2% because of a more favorable product mix and price increases. Liberty Corner, N.J.-based Fedders also said it won't be able to file its second-quarter financial report with the Securities and Exchange Commission, as it hasn't yet filed its Form 10-K for 2004 or its report for the first quarter of 2005. CORRECT: Stereotaxis quarterly loss widens (6:39 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Stereotaxis Inc. STXS, +0.75% after Thursday's closing bell reported a second-quarter net loss of $11.5 million, or 42 cents a share, compared with a loss of $8.4 million, or $5.46 a share, last year. The number of shares used in computing the period's net loss was 27.3 million, compared with 1.5 million a year ago. Revenue rose 57% to $6.1 million from $3.9 million last year. The St. Louis manufacturer of cardiology instrument control systems forecast 2005 revenue of $22 million to $26 million, citing a delay in an expected approval from the Food and Drug Administration of three catheters. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expect revenue of $32 million and a loss of 97 cents a share. (Corrects day of week Stereotaxis reported results.) Axcan Pharma quarterly profit drops 67%; rev down 4.2% (6:01 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Axcan Pharma Inc. AXCA after Thursday's closing bell reported fiscal third-quarter net earnings of $4.1 million, or 9 cents a share, a 67% decrease from $12.6 million, or 25 cents a share, last year. Pro forma earnings were $3 million, or 6 cents a share. Revenue fell 4.2% to $59.4 million from $62 million a year ago. The company attributed its lower sales to a decline in U.S. wholesaler inventory levels of its products. Slumping sales drag down Pep Boys' second-quarter results (5:54 PM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch) -- Slumping sales of both merchandise and service dragged down Pep Boys' results in the second quarter. The auto parts retailer said Thursday that on a continuing operations basis, it earned just $832,000, or a penny a share, on the period. That is down from $13.5 million and 22 cents a year ago and far below the 11-cent average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue came in at $577.4 million, down nearly 3% while same-store sales fell 2.5%. Shares of Pep Boys PBY, -2.02% ended the day down 1% at $12.85. Isle of Capri profit tumbles (5:18 PM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch) -- Isle of Capri Casinos earned $4 million, or 13 cents a share, in its fiscal first quarter. That is down from the $10.6 million or 35 cents a share it earned in the year-ago period and 2 cents shy of the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Total revenue came in at $281.5 million, slightly ahead the $278.7 million of the same quarter in fiscal 2005. Shares of Isle ISLE ended the day down 5.5% at $25.80. DreamWorks reiterates '05 forecast, swings to 2Q loss (5:18 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- DreamWorks Animation SKG DWA after the market closed Thursday reaffimed its 2005 outlook of earnings in the range of 80 cents to 90 cents a share and said it swung to a second-quarter loss amid weaker-than-expected DVD sales of "Shrek 2." DreamWorks said it lost $3.7 million, or 4 cents a share, a total that includes a tax benefit of $2 million, or 2 cents a share. In the year-ago period, it earned $146.1 million, or $1.89 a share. Revenue fell to $35.4 million from $300.3 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were expecting a loss of 7 cents a share on revenue of $27.7 million. "Results for the quarter are slightly ahead of where we said they would be on our July 11 conference call, driven by the strength of 'Madagascar' consumer products as well as our library," said Jeffrey Katzenberg, DreamWorks Animation's CEO, in a statement. Emulex swings to a quarterly profit (4:58 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Emulex Corp. ELX, -4.29% after Thursday's closing bell reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $25.3 million, or 28 cents a share. In the same quarter last year, the company reported a net loss of $572.9 million, or $6.97 a share. Pro forma per-share profit in the quarter was 30 cents vs. 18 cents a year ago. Revenue at the Costa Mesa, Calif.-based storage networking hardware company rose to $108.2 million from $86.4 million last year. The company expects fiscal first-quarter earnings of 16 cents to 18 cents a share, or 26 cents to 28 cents a share on a pro forma basis. It sees first-quarter revenue in the range of $106 million to $110 million. Leap Wireless swings to 2Q profit; ups 2005 view (4:51 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Leap Wireless International Inc. LEAP after Thursday's closing bell reported second-quarter net earnings of $2.5 million, or 4 cents a share. Last year, the company posted a loss of $18.3 million, or 31 cents a share. Revenue rose to $226.8 million, up from $205.7 million a year ago. The San Diego-based wireless communication services provider raised the top end of its fiscal 2005 revenue forecast to a range of $910 million to $950 million, from $890 million to $950 million. It also raised its 2005 adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization forecast to a range of $265 million and $285 million, from $245 million to $270 million. Weight Watchers 2Q profit drops on transaction charges (4:44 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Weight Watchers International Inc. WTW, +1.51% after Thursday's closing bell reported second-quarter net earnings of $34.5 million, or 33 cents a share, down 35% from $52.9 million, or 49 cents a share, a year ago. Excluding charges related to its acquisition of the remaining portion of WeightWatchers.com, the company would have reported second-quarter earnings of $60.4 million, or 58 cents a share. Second-quarter revenue rose to $312.6 million from $264.9 million a year ago. The weight loss management company also said it now sees fiscal 2005 earnings of $1.91 to $1.98 a share, excluding transaction-related expenses. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expect earnings of $1.93 a share on sales of $1.08 billion. Nvidia quarterly profit surges (4:34 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Nvidia Corp. NVDA, +4.63% after Thursday's closing bell reported second-quarter net income of $74.8 million, or 41 cents a share, vs. $5.1 million, or 3 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had estimated earnings at 34 cents a share. Revenue at the Santa Clara, Calif.-based graphic and digital media processor company rose to $574.8 million from $456.1 million last year. Analysts had expected revenue of $585 million. Cree earnings flat in fourth fiscal quarter (4:31 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Cree Inc. CREE, +1.87% saw earnings remain flat in its fourth fiscal quarter despite a 9% gain in revenue over the previous year. For the quarter, the company reported earnings of $21 million, or 27 cents a share, compared to earnings of $21 million, or 28 cents a share, for the same period last year. Revenue rose to $98.9 million from $90.9 million last year. Analysts were expecting earnings of 27 cents a share on revenue of $100.6 million, according to data from Thomson First Call. The company also forecast earnings and revenue for the first fiscal quarter that were below analysts' estimates. Dell falls 6% in late trading as 2Q sales, 3Q forecast, lags (4:15 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Dell Inc. shares fell 6% in late trading after the top PC maker reported second-quarter sales that missed Wall Street estimates by almost $300 million and issued a third-quarter sales forecast that also fell just shy of analyst expectations. Dell fell to $37.20 a share. Analog Devices profit sinks 28% as revenue falls 19% (4:15 PM ET) LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- Analog Devices Inc. ADI, +1.36% late Thursday said its fiscal third-quarter profit sank 28% as revenue slumped on weaker sales of digital-signal processor products to wireless handset customers in Asia. The company earned $121.4 million, or 32 cents a share, for the period, down from $169.1 million, or 43 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue for the period ended July 30 fell 19% to $582.4 million from $717.8 million. Wall Street analysts, on average, expected the company to earn 31 cents a share on revenue of $583.2 million, according to a Thomson First Call survey. Looking ahead, the company predicted fiscal fourth-quarter earnings of 32 cents to 34 cents a share -- in line with the average analyst estimate calling for earnings of 33 cents a share. Jamdat Mobile profits jump five-fold (4:13 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Jamdat Mobile Inc. JMDT on Thursday after the market close reported second quarter revenue that rose 128% from the same period last year. Revenue for the period was $19.3 million compared to $8.4 million last year. Net income for the quarter came in at $2.6 million, or 11 cents a share, compared to profits of $0.4 million for last year. The company said profits excluding certain charges were $7.2 million, or 30 cents a share. Analysts were expecting profits of 19 cents a share on revenue of $19.3 million, according to consensus estimates from Thomson First Call. Shares of Jamdat traded down 16% to $24.80 in after-hours trades. Kohl's earnings up, topping estimate, as revenue climbs 16% (4:11 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Kohl's Corp. KSS, +1.47% after the closing bell Thursday posted a second-quarter profit of $187 million, or 54 cents a share, as revenue climbed 16% to $2.89 billion. In the year-ago period, the general-merchandise retailer earned $147 million, or 47 cents a share. Wall Street expected Kohl's to make 52 cents a share on revenue of $2.89 billion. Dell Inc. profit rises to $1.02 billion (4:05 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Dell Inc. DELL on Thursday posted a second-quarter profit of $1.02 billion, or 41 cents a share, compared to $799 million, or 31 cents a share in the year-ago quarter. Excluding one-time items, Dell earned 38 cents a share, to meet the 38 cents a share estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Revenue rose to $13.43 billion from $11.7 billion. However, the company's revenue fell short of analysts' $13.7 billion estimate. Cardiome Pharma quarterly loss narrows (3:26 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Cardiome Pharma Corp. CRME, +3.11% (CA:COM)on Thursday posted a second-quarter net loss of C$7.66 million, or 15 Canadian cents a share, compared with a loss of C$9.84 million, or 25 Canadian cents a share, in the same quarter last year. Revenue at the Vancouver, British Columbia-based cardiovascular drug company fell to C$3.81 million from C$5.27 million. Cardiome said it expects to post losses for the next two fiscal years as it continues to develop its RSD1235 (oral) and oxypurinol CHF product candidates. Triarc Cos swings to quarterly profit (3:15 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Triarc Companies Inc. TRY, +2.00% TRY on Thursday reported a second-quarter profit of $419,000, or a penny a share. In the same period a year earlier, the Arby's restaurant franchisor lost $1.28 million, or 2 cents a share. Sales rose to $93.7 million from $77.5 million. Arby's same-store sales rose 3% in the quarter. Broadcom may take charge for Siliquent Tech acquisition (2:56 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Broadcom Corp. BRCM on Thursday completed its $75.5 million acquisition of network interface controller developer Siliquent Technologies Inc. The company said it may take a related charge for purchased in-process research and development expenses in the third quarter, though it's unsure how much that charge would be. Lifecore Biomedical sees higher expenses in first half (1:59 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Lifecore Biomedical Inc. LCBM dropped 20% to $10.87 on Thursday after the Chaska, Minn., medical device maker posted fourth-quarter earnings before items of $2.3 million, or 17 cents a share, on sales of $14.8 million but forecast a sequential drop in performance for its fiscal first-quarter. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimater for the company's results. Saying it expects growth in fiscal 2006 to come largely in the second half, the company forecast earnings of 4 to 6 cents a share on sales of between $12.6 million and $13 million for the September quarter. Lifecore also said it expects expenses to be higher in the first half of fiscal 2006 due to new product launches. Kintera cutting workforce; to report results next week (1:48 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Kintera Inc. KNTA said on Thursday that it is cutting 10% of its workforce. The company expects to complete the job cuts by the end of the third quarter. The San Diego-based software company also said it expects to release its first half financial results next week. On Monday, Kintera postponed the release of its second-quarter results due to a pending restatement of its first-quarter financials and a related filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company said in a statement that it expects to report a "significant increase" in its second-quarter net loss compared with the same period last year. Kintera forecast second-quarter revenue to be up more than 75% vs. last year. Datatrack Int'l tumbles following earnings report (1:47 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Datatrack International Inc. DATA, +2.05% fell almost 21% to $16.50 Thursday after the Cleveland-based provider of electronic data capture software posted second-quarter earnings of $261,000, or 3 cents a share, on revenue of $3.7 million. In the same period a year earlier, the company earned $89,000, or a penny a share, on revenue of $2.6 million. Backlog as of June 30 stood at $17.9 million. Advance Auto Parts falls 5% after earnings (1:43 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Advance Auto Parts AAP, +2.22% shed almost 5% to $66.27 Thursday after Smith Barney downgraded the aftermarket auto-parts and maintenance retailer to hold from buy in the wake of its second-quarter earnings report. After the market closed on Wednesday, the Roanake, Va.-based company posted earnings of $65.9 million, or 90 cents a share, up from $53.2 million, or 70 cents a share, a year ago. Ninetowns' shares plummet on weak outlook (12:16 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Ninetowns World Trading Holdings Ltd. NINE, +5.87% dropped almost 30% to $5.30, putting it at the top of Nasdaq's percentage decliners list on Thursday. The move comes after the China-based developer of import/export processing-related software reported second-quarter earnings of $5.1 million, or 14 cents a share, in line with the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call, but the company lowered its outlook for the full year due to a change in policy at the Chinese inspections administration. The company, which expects the change to result in heavier competition, now sees earnings of 44 to 50 cents a share for the year ending Dec. 31 on revenue of between $26.5 million and $30.5 million. Wall Street's current consensus estimate is for earnings of 66 cents a share for the year. Freddie Mac: 30-year mortgage averages 5.89% vs 5.82% (11:18 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- U.S. fixed-rate mortgages rose in the week ending Thursday, with the benchmark 30-year loan rising to 5.89% from 5.82% a week earlier, Freddie Mac FRE, +0.00% said. The mortgage agency said its weekly survey also showed a rise in the 15-year loan, to 5.47% from 5.38%, and the one-year Treasury-indexed adjustable rate, which averaged 4.57% vs. 4.47% a week earlier. The five-year hybrid ARM also rose, to 5.4% from 5.3%. "The stronger-than-expected employment report coupled with upward revisions in job growth for the previous two months renewed the market's fear of inflation," said Frank Nothaft, vice president and chief economist at Freddie Mac, in a statement. "That's because strong job growth can put upward pressure on wages - a key factor in inflation - that in turn, can drive long-term rates higher." Freddie Mac expects to see some moderation in housing activity as mortgage rates rise, but it still expects 2005 to be a record year for sales and new construction. CAE quarterly profit falls, revenue rises (11:00 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- CAE Inc. CGT, -1.43% [ca:cae] on Thursday reported first-quarter net earnings of C$20.8 milllion, or 8 Canadian cents a share, compared with C$24.3 milllion, or 10 cents a share, in the same quarter a year earlier. Revenue at the Montreal-based company, which provides simulation technologies and integrated training services for the aviation and defence industries, rose to C$266 million from $230.9 million. Atlantic American earns 4 cents vs 4 cents (9:48 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Atlantic American Corp. AAME, +3.13% on Thursday said that it earned $1.2 million, or 4 cents a share in the second quarter, vs. $1.1 million, or 4 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Revenue was $50.2 million, increasing 6% over 2004 second-quarter revenue of $47.4 million. Shares in the Atlanta-based insurance company were unchanged in early trading at $2.87. Elizabeth Arden narrows loss on rising sales (9:44 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Elizabeth Arden Inc. RDEN on Thursday said its fourth-quarter net loss narrowed to $4.5 million, or 16 cents a share, from $9.1 million, or $1.12 cents, a year ago. Excluding a charge for the sale of a facility, the net loss would have been 11 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call forecast a loss, on average, of 13 cents a share. Revenue for the period ended June 30 increased to $187.1 million from $154.6 million in last year's fourth quarter. For the first quarter, the New York-based beauty and cosmetics company expects earnings of 5 to 6 cents a share, well below analysts' view for 21 cents a share. However, for the second quarter Arden sees earnings at $1.25 to $1.28, ahead of analysts' view for $1.16 a share. Fiscal 2006 earnings are targeted at $1.50 to $1.55, bracketing analysts view for $1.53 a share. Chesapeake Corp. narrows loss (9:20 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Chesapeake Corp. CSK, -8.86% said Thursday that its second-quarter loss from continuing operations widened to $2 million, or 10 cents a share, from a restated $400,000, or 2 cents, a year ago. The company said it's restating its financial results for 2004 and the first quarter of 2005 as a result of accounting errors. Excluding charges, income from continuing operations would have been $4.4 million, or 23 cents a share. Sales increased to $259.9 million form $239.3 million in last year's second quarter. Shares in the Richmond, Va., paperboard and plastic packaging company closed Wednesday at $19.60, down 9 cents a share. Allied Healthcare profit rises (9:02 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Allied Healthcare International Inc. AHCI said Thursday that third-quarter net income rose to $4.7 million from $3.3 million a year ago. Earnings available to common shareholders remained unchanged at 10 cents a share year over year. Revenue for the period ended June 30 rose to $89.5 million from $81.9 million in last year's third quarter. Shares in the New York-based healthcare staffing firm closed Wednesday at $7.32, up 7 cents. 1-800 Flowers.com posts in-line earns (8:58 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- 1-800 Flowers.com FLWS, -0.42% Thursday reported fourth-quarter earnings of $3.6 million, or 6 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $30.4 million, or 45 cents a share. Last year's quarter included a gain of $19.5 million from a tax benefit. Revenue jumped 15.2% in the latest three months to $186.1 million from $161.6 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 6 cents a share in the June period. Looking ahead, the online flower seller forecast revenue growth of 14-to-16% in the second half. The stock closed Wednesday at $7.43, up 3.6%. Target tops Wall St. earnings view by 2c (8:34 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Target Corp. TGT, +0.36% Thursday reported second-quarter earnings from continuing operations of $540 million, or 61 cents a share, up from a year-ago equivalent profit of $360 million, or 39 cents a share. Revenue rose 13.6% in the latest three months to $11.99 billion from $10.56 billion in the same period a year earlier. Same-store sales increased 6.7% in the June period. The Minneapolis-based general merchandise retailer attributed the sales improvement to the strong comps, new store expansion and its credit card operations. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 59 cents a share in the latest quarter. Looking ahead, Target said it believes it's "well-positioned" for "profitable market share growth" for the rest of 2005. The stock closed Wednesday at $55.54, up 12 cents. Five Star Quality Care profit, sales rise (8:30 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Five Star Quality Care Inc. FVE, -1.89% said Thursday that second-quarter profit advanced to $1.2 million, or 10 cents a share, from $943,000, or 11 cents, in the year ago period. Earnings per share declined because of a greater number of shares outstanding in the most recent quarter. Revenue for the period ended June 30 increased to $186.2 million from $153.3 million in last year's second quarter. Shares in the Newton, Mass.-based healthcare services company closed Wednesday at $8.85, down 9 cents. ICO Inc. profits fall due to volume decline (8:28 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- ICO Inc. ICOC Thursday reported earnings from continuing operations of $19,000, or breakeven on a per share basis, for the third quarter, down from a year-ago equivalent profit of $397,000, or a penny a share. Revenue rose 9% in the latest three months to $75.8 million from $66.8 million in the same period a year earlier. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate for the company's results. The Houston-based maker of polymer powders and film concentrates said results fell year-over-year due to a 7% decline in sales and service volumes in the quarter. The stock closed Wednesday at $2.66, up 4 cents. Beacon Roofing Q2 earnings 41c vs loss 17c (8:27 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Beacon Roofing Supply Inc. BECN, +0.38% said Thursday it's third-quarter net income rose to $11.3 million, or 41 cents a share, from a loss of $3 million, or 17 cents, a year earlier. Sales at the Peabody, Mass., building products company rose 38% to $248.4 million. MWI Veterinary third-quarter profit rises (8:25 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- MWI Veterinary Supply, Inc. MWIV said third-quarter profit rose to $1.4 million, or 24 cents a share, from $717 million, or 12 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter. Revenue for the period climbed 30% to $138 million. Four Seasons profit, revenue rise (8:23 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Four Seasons Hotels Inc. FS said Thursday that second-quarter profit rose to $15.8 million, or 42 cents a share, from $12.8 million, or 34 cents, a year ago. Revenue for the period ended June 30 rose to $74.5 million form $71.4 million in last year's second quarter. U.S.-listed shares in the Toronto-based hotel operator closed up $2.98 at $66.98 Wednesday. Jacuzzi Brands sees FY05 earns below prior views (8:21 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Jacuzzi Brands JJZ Thursday reported third-quarter earnings from continuing operations $37.9 million, or 50 cents a share, up from a year-ago equivalent profit of $16.9 million, or 22 cents a share. Sales at the West Palm Beach, Fla., maker of bath and plumbing products rose in the latest three months to $334.2 million from $331.2 million in the same period a year earlier. The latest results include a gain of 34 cents a share from an asset sale, a gain of 6 cents a share from a tax benefit, and a restructuring charge of a penny a share. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 21 cents a share in the June period on sales of $365.2 million. Looking ahead, Jacuzzi Brands sees earnings from continuing operations, excluding items, of 40 to 44 cents a share for fiscal 2005. The company said this outlook is below prior estimates due to continued softness in the U.K. and Italian bath businesses and U.S. spa markets, and a shift toward lower margin products in the U.K. and Italian bath businesses. The stock closed Wednesday at $9.15, down 2.2%. Brinker Int'l tops by a penny in June quarter (8:12 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Brinker International EAT, +0.03% Thursday reported fourth-quarter earnings of $49.8 million, or 55 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $63.7 million, 62 cents a share. On an adjusted basis, excluding, a number of gains and charges, the Dallas-based restaurant operator earned $63.8 million, or 71 cents a share, in the June period. Revenue rose in the latest three months to $1.04 billion from $1.02 billion in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 70 cents a share in the quarter. Looking ahead, the operator of Chili's, Macaroni Grill, On the Border and Maggiano's restaurants forecast earnings before items of 45 to 47 cents a share for the first quarter, and $2.40 to $2.46 a share for the full year. Wall Street's current consensus estimates are for profits of 44 cents a share and $2.42 a share in the respective periods. The stock closed Wednesday at $39.64, up 2 cents. CP Ships reports jump in profit, outlook lifted (7:59 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - CP Ships Ltd. TEU reported net income of $33 million, or 37 cents a share, compared with $3 million, or 3 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Revenue rose 18% to $1.06 billion for the oil tanker shipper. CP Ships said volume in 2005 would be similar to 2004, with freight rates improving. The Gatwick, U.K.-based company raised its 2005 earnings outlook to $1.40 to $1.60 a share from $1.30 to $1.50 a share. LSI Industries lifts financial outlook (7:55 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- LSI Industries LYTS, +0.50% Thursday increased its financial outlook for fiscal 2005 to earnings of 73 to 74 cents a share, up from its prior projection for a profit of 68 to 70 cents a share. Shares of the Cincinnati lighting fixtures maker closed Wednesday at $14.26, down 12 cents. Hospira Inc. profit falls as sales dip (7:52 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Hospira Inc. HSP, +0.18% a maker of hospital products, reported second-quarter net income of $72 million, or 44 cents a share, compared with $125.8 million, or 80 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Sales in the period ended June 30 fell 0.8% to $661.9 million, on a decline in sales to Abbott Laboratories, its former parent. Manhattan Associates to pay $50M for Evant (7:46 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Manhattan Associates Inc. MANH, +1.48% Thursday said it agreed to acquire supply chain software maker Evant Inc. for about $50 million in cash. The deal is expected to close by Sept. 30. The transaction is expected to be about 2 cents a share dilutive to Manhattan Associates' fourth quarter adjusted earnings per share and is expected to add about 3 cents a share to the company's 2006 earnings. On Wednesday the company's stock closed unchanged at $21.20. Trans World Entertainment swings to loss on weak comps (7:44 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Trans World Entertainment Corp. TWMC, -3.85% Thursday reported a second-quarter loss of $7 million, or 21 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $9.3 million, or 25 cents a share. The latest results include a charge of $1.1 million, or 3 cents a share, from a change in Ohio state tax regulations. Sales fell in the latest three months to $253.1 million from $277.2 million in the same period a year earlier. Same-store sales for the Albany, N.Y., music and video products retailer fell 5% in the June period. The average estimate of a single analyst polled by Thomson First Call was for a loss of 15 cents a share in the quarter. Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations The following is management's discussion and analysis of the financial condition and results of operations of Atlantic American Corporation ("Atlantic American" or the "Parent") and its subsidiaries (collectively with the Parent, the "Company") for the years ended December 31, 2017 and 2016. This discussion should be read in conjunction with the consolidated financial statements and notes thereto included elsewhere herein. Atlantic American is an insurance holding company whose operations are conducted primarily through its insurance subsidiaries: American Southern Insurance Company and American Safety Insurance Company (together known as "American Southern") in the property and casualty insurance industry, and Bankers Fidelity Life Insurance Company and Bankers Fidelity Assurance Company (together known as "Bankers Fidelity") in the life and health insurance industry. Each operating company is managed separately, offers different products and is evaluated on its individual performance. Critical Accounting Policies The accounting and reporting policies of the Company are in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America ("GAAP") and, in management's belief, conform to general practices within the insurance industry. The following is an explanation of the Company's accounting policies and the resultant estimates considered most significant by management. These accounting policies inherently require significant judgment and assumptions and actual operating results could differ significantly from management's estimates determined using these policies. Atlantic American does not expect that changes in the estimates determined using these policies will have a material effect on the Company's financial condition or liquidity, although changes could have a material effect on its consolidated results of operations. Unpaid loss and loss adjustment expenses comprised 29% of the Company's total liabilities at December 31, 2017. This liability includes estimates for: 1) unpaid losses on claims reported prior to December 31, 2017, 2) future development on those reported claims, 3) unpaid ultimate losses on claims incurred prior to December 31, 2017 but not yet reported and 4) unpaid loss adjustment expenses for reported and unreported claims incurred prior to December 31, 2017. Quantification of loss estimates for each of these components involves a significant degree of judgment and estimates may vary, materially, from period to period. Estimated unpaid losses on reported claims are developed based on historical experience with similar claims by the Company. Development on reported claims, estimates of unpaid ultimate losses on claims incurred prior to December 31, 2017 but not yet reported, and estimates of unpaid loss adjustment expenses are developed based on the Company's historical experience, using actuarial methods to assist in the analysis. The Company's actuaries develop ranges of estimated development on reported and unreported claims as well as loss adjustment expenses using various methods, including the paid-loss development method, the reported-loss development method, the paid Bornhuetter-Ferguson method and the reported Bornhuetter-Ferguson method. Any single method used to estimate ultimate losses has inherent advantages and disadvantages due to the trends and changes affecting the business environment and the Company's administrative policies. Further, external factors, such as legislative changes, medical cost inflation, and others may directly or indirectly impact the relative adequacy of liabilities for unpaid losses and loss adjustment expenses. The Company's approach is to select an estimate of ultimate losses based on comparing results of a variety of reserving methods, as opposed to total reliance on any single method. Unpaid loss and loss adjustment expenses are reviewed periodically for significant lines of business, and when current results differ from the original assumptions used to develop such estimates, the amount of the Company's recorded liability for unpaid loss and loss adjustment expenses is adjusted. In the event the Company's actual reported losses in any period are materially in excess of the previously estimated amounts, such losses, to the extent reinsurance coverage does not exist, could have a material adverse effect on the Company's results of operations. TABLE OF CONTENTS Future policy benefits comprised 36% of the Company's total liabilities at December 31, 2017. These liabilities relate primarily to life insurance products and are based upon assumed future investment yields, mortality rates, and withdrawal rates after giving effect to possible risks of adverse deviation. The assumed mortality and withdrawal rates are based upon the Company's experience. If actual results differ from the initial assumptions, the amount of the Company's recorded liability could require adjustment. Deferred acquisition costs comprised 10% of the Company's total assets at December 31, 2017. Deferred acquisition costs are commissions, premium taxes, and other incremental direct costs of contract acquisition that results directly from and are essential to the contract transaction(s) and would not have been incurred by the Company had the contract transaction(s) not occurred. The deferred amounts are recorded as an asset on the balance sheet and amortized to expense in a systematic manner. Traditional life insurance and long-duration health insurance deferred policy acquisition costs are amortized over the estimated premium-paying period of the related policies using assumptions consistent with those used in computing the related liability for policy benefit reserves. Deferred acquisition costs for property and casualty insurance and short-duration health insurance are amortized over the effective period of the related insurance policies. Deferred policy acquisition costs are expensed when such costs are deemed not to be recoverable from future premiums (for traditional life and long-duration health insurance) and from the related unearned premiums and investment income (for property and casualty and short-duration health insurance). Assessments of recoverability for property and casualty and short-duration health insurance are extremely sensitive to the estimates of a subsequent year's projected losses related to the unearned premiums. Projected loss estimates for a current block of business for which unearned premiums remain to be earned may vary significantly from the indicated losses incurred in any previous calendar year. Receivables are amounts due from reinsurers, insureds and agents, and any sales of investment securities not yet settled, and comprised 9% of the Company's total assets at December 31, 2017. Insured and agent balances are evaluated periodically for collectibility. Annually, the Company performs an analysis of the creditworthiness of the reinsurers with whom the Company contracts using various data sources. Failure of reinsurers to meet their obligations due to insolvencies, disputes or otherwise could result in uncollectible amounts and losses to the Company. Allowances for uncollectible amounts are established, as and when a loss has been determined probable, against the related receivable. Losses are recognized by the Company when determined on a specific account basis and a general provision for loss is made based on the Company's historical experience. Cash and investments comprised 79% of the Company's total assets at December 31, 2017. Substantially all of the Company's investments are in bonds and common and preferred stocks, the values of which are subject to significant market fluctuations. The Company carries all fixed maturities, which includes bonds and redeemable preferred stocks, and equity securities, which includes common and non-redeemable preferred stocks, as available for sale and, accordingly, at their estimated fair values. The Company owns certain fixed maturities that do not have publicly quoted values, but had an estimated fair value as determined by management of $1.4 million at December 31, 2017. Such values inherently involve a greater degree of judgment and uncertainty and therefore ultimately greater price volatility than the value of securities with publicly quoted market values. On occasion, the value of an investment may decline to a value below its amortized purchase price and remain at such value for an extended period of time. When an investment's indicated fair value has declined below its cost basis for a period of time, the Company evaluates such investment for an other than temporary impairment. The evaluation for an other than temporary impairment is a quantitative and qualitative process, which is subject to risks and uncertainties in the determination of whether declines in the fair value of investments are other than temporary. Potential risks and uncertainties include, among other things, changes in general economic conditions, an issuer's financial condition or near term recovery prospects and the effects of changes in interest rates. In evaluating a potential impairment, the Company considers, among other factors, management's intent and ability to hold the securities until price recovery, the nature of the investment and the expectation of prospects for the issuer and its industry, the status of an issuer's continued satisfaction of its obligations in accordance with their contractual terms, and management's expectation as to the issuer's ability and intent to continue to do so, as well as ratings actions that may affect the issuer's credit status. If an other than temporary impairment is deemed to exist, then the Company will write down the amortized cost basis of the investment to its estimated fair value. While any such write down does not impact the reported value of the investment in the Company's balance sheet, it is reflected as a realized investment loss in the Company's consolidated statements of operations in the period incurred. TABLE OF CONTENTS The Company determines the fair values of certain financial instruments based on the fair value hierarchy established in Accounting Standards Codification ("ASC") 820-10-20, Fair Value Measurements and Disclosures ("ASC 820-10-20"). The fair values of fixed maturities and equity securities are largely determined by either independent methods prescribed by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, which do not differ materially from nationally quoted market prices, when available, or independent broker quotations. See Note 2 and Note 14 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements with respect to assets and liabilities carried at fair value and information about the inputs used to value those financial instruments, by hierarchy level, in accordance with ASC 820-10-20. Deferred income taxes reflect the effect of temporary differences between assets and liabilities that are recognized for financial reporting purposes and the amounts that are recognized for tax purposes. These deferred income taxes are measured by applying currently enacted tax laws and rates. Valuation allowances are recognized to reduce the deferred tax asset to the amount that is deemed more likely than not to be realized. In assessing the likelihood of realization, management considers estimates of future taxable income and tax planning strategies. Premiums are earned ratably over their respective policy terms, and therefore premiums earned in the current year are related to policies written during both the current year and immediately preceding year. The performance of an insurance company is often measured by its combined ratio. The combined ratio represents the percentage of losses, loss adjustment expenses and other expenses that are incurred for each dollar of premium earned by the company. A combined ratio of under 100% represents an underwriting profit while a combined ratio of over 100% indicates an underwriting loss. The combined ratio is divided into two components, the loss ratio (the ratio of losses and loss adjustment expenses incurred to premiums earned) and the expense ratio (the ratio of expenses incurred to premiums earned). In establishing reserves, American Southern initially reserves for losses at the higher end of the reasonable range if no other value within the range is determined to be more probable. Selection of such an initial loss estimate is an attempt by management to give recognition that initial claims information received generally is not conclusive with respect to legal liability, is generally not comprehensive with respect to magnitude of loss and generally, based on historical experience, will develop more adversely as time passes and more information becomes available. However, as a result, American Southern generally experiences reserve redundancies when analyzing the development of prior year losses in a current period. At December 31, 2017, the range of estimates developed in connection with the loss reserves for American Southern indicated that reserves could be as much as 9.7% lower or as much as 12.1% higher. Development from prior years' reserves has historically reduced the current year loss ratio; however, such reduction in the current year loss ratio is generally offset by the reserves established in the current year for current period losses. American Southern's estimated net reserve redundancies for the years ended December 31, 2017 and 2016 were $2.5 million and $2.1 million, respectively. Management believes that such differences will continue in future periods but is unable to determine if or when incremental redundancies will increase or decrease, until the underlying losses are ultimately settled. Contingent commissions, if contractually applicable, are ultimately payable to participating agents based on the underlying profitability of a particular insurance contract or a group of insurance contracts, and are periodically evaluated and accrued as earned. In periods in which loss reserves reflect favorable development from prior years' reserves, there is generally a highly correlated increase in commission expense also related to the prior year business. content: ATLANTA, Mar 26, 2018 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE via COMTEX) -- Atlantic American Corporation AAME, +3.13% today reported its results for the fourth quarter and year ended December 31, 2017. For the fourth quarter ended December 31, 2017, the Company reported net income of $2.5 million, or $0.12 per diluted share, up from $1.3 million, or $0.06 per diluted share, in the fourth quarter of 2016. The increase was attributable to an increase in realized investment gains of $5.2 million during the fourth quarter of 2017. Premiums for the fourth quarter of 2017 increased 10.6% to $40.3 million compared to $36.5 million for the fourth quarter of 2016, primarily as a result of premium growth in the Medicare supplement line of business in the life and health operation. Net income for the year ended December 31, 2017 was $4.5 million, or $0.20 per diluted share, as compared to $2.6 million, or $0.11 per diluted share, for the year ended December 31, 2016. Total premiums earned during 2017 increased 6.4% to $163.3 million from $153.5 million in 2016. Premiums in the property and casualty operation decreased slightly in 2017 as compared to 2016; but were offset by a 10.0% premium increase in the life and health operations in the comparable years. Benefits and losses increased 13.9% in 2017 as compared with 2016; while commissions and underwriting expenses decreased 3.0% over the comparable prior year period. Realized investment gains were $9.2 million in 2017 as compared to $2.6 million in 2016. Commenting on the results, Hilton H. Howell, Jr., chairman, president and chief executive officer, stated, "We are delighted to close out another profitable year and are enthusiastic about our prospects for 2018. In the fourth quarter of 2017, the Company reported a significant realized gain due to the conclusion of one of the Company's real estate partnerships. While the life and health operation experienced some growing pains over the last year, we have completed a number of strategic pricing adjustments for our Medicare supplement product and expect loss experience trends to normalize. Our property and casualty operation continues to perform exceedingly well and reported an improvement in net income over the prior year. In recognition of our enthusiasm for 2018, our Board of Directors recently approved our 7th consecutive annual dividend of $0.02 per share to shareholders of record on April 13, 2018, payable on or about April 23, 2018." Atlantic American is an insurance holding company involved through its subsidiary companies in specialty markets of the life, health, and property and casualty insurance industries. Its principal insurance subsidiaries are American Southern Insurance Company, American Safety Insurance Company, Bankers Fidelity Life Insurance Company and Bankers Fidelity Assurance Company. content: OLDWICK, N.J., Mar 01, 2018 (BUSINESS WIRE) -- A.M. Best has affirmed the Financial Strength Rating (FSR) of A (Excellent) and the Long-Term Issuer Credit Ratings (Long-Term ICR) of “a” of American Southern Insurance Company (Topeka, KS) and its wholly owned and 100% reinsured subsidiary, American Safety Insurance Company (collectively referred to as American Southern Group). Additionally, A.M. Best has affirmed the FSR of A-(Excellent) and the Long-Term ICR of “a-” of Bankers Fidelity Life Insurance Company and Bankers Fidelity Assurance Company (collectively referred to as Bankers Fidelity Life Insurance Group [BFLIG]. The outlooks of these Credit Ratings (ratings) are stable. All companies are domiciled Atlanta GA, unless otherwise specified. Concurrently, A.M. Best has affirmed the Long-Term ICR of “bbb-” of the parent company, Atlantic American Corporation (Atlantic American) AAME, +3.13% The outlooks of these ratings remain stable. The ratings reflect American Southern Group’s balance sheet strength, which A.M. Best categorizes as very strong, as well as its adequate operating performance, neutral business profile and appropriate enterprise risk management (ERM). The ratings also reflect the group’s long history of operating profitability, management’s disciplined underwriting approach and its local market knowledge. American Southern Group’s balance sheet strength assessment reflects risk-adjusted capitalization that is at the strongest level, as measured by Best’s Capital Adequacy Ratio (BCAR) model, partially offset by the group’s payment of substantial stockholder dividends, which historically have been used to service debt held at Atlantic American. The ratings also consider the financial leverage and interest coverage at Atlantic American, with its adjusted debt-to-total capital at 16.3% as of Sept. 30, 2017. Interest coverage historically has been supported adequately by the insurance operating companies’ ability to generate sufficient earnings to cover obligations at the parent. Negative rating actions could occur for American Southern Group if there is significant deterioration in underwriting results over the near term, or if risk-adjusted capitalization declines significantly. The ratings of BFLIG consider its balance sheet strength, which is categorized as very strong, combined with its marginal operating performance, a neutral business profile and its appropriate ERM. In the rating of BFLIG, A.M. Best has considered the execution of BFLIG’s modernization of overall operations. Management has taken these steps with the hopes of achieving better competitive positioning as newly designed products and a multi-phased expansion are being implemented, both into new markets and via broader based distribution channels. While BFLIG has exhibited higher premium revenue development over the last year, there has also been a negative development on the bottom line related to new business strain. Positive rating actions could occur for BFLIG if there is a sustained positive earnings trend. Negative rating action could occur if there is a material weakening in its risk-adjusted capitalization. Today's free coverage is available at: www.active-investors.com/registration-sg/?symbol=MET Earnings Highlights and Summary For the quarter ended September 30, 2017, MetLife's total revenue grew 2% to $16.78 billion on a y-o-y basis compared to $16.01 billion in Q3 2016, and was ahead of analysts' estimates of $15.52 billion. MetLife's Premiums, Fees and Other revenues were $12.61 billion for Q3 2017, up 9% compared to $11.54 billion in Q3 2016. MetLife reported a net loss of $87 million in Q3 2017 compared to a net income of $571 million in Q3 2016, including $1.1 billion of separation-related charges in Brighthouse Financial, Inc. On a per share basis, the Company's net loss was $0.08 compared to a net income of $0.51 in the prior year's same period. MetLife reported operating earnings of $1.17 billion, down 14% compared to $1.36 billion in Q3 2016. On a per share basis, the Company's operating earnings were $1.09, down 11% versus $1.22 per share in the year ago comparable period, and beating Wall Street's estimates of $0.89 per share. As of September 30, 2017, MetLife's book value was $51.83 per share, down 25% from $69.35 per share at September 30, 2016, primarily due to the separation of Brighthouse. The Company's book value, excluding accumulated other comprehensive income (AOCI), other than foreign currency translation adjustments (FCTA), was $40.96 per share, down 23% from $53.40 per share at September 30, 2016. Segment Results During Q3 2017, MetLife's total operating earnings for the US segment were $546 million, down 1% on a y-o-y basis, with a favorable underwriting and volume growth offset by lower interest margins. For the reported quarter, the Company's operating premiums, fees, and other revenues were $7.4 billion, up 17% on a y-o-y basis. For Q3 2017, MetLife's operating earnings for the Group Benefits segment surged 30% to $241 million. The segment's operating premiums, fees, and other revenues were $4.1 billion for the reported quarter, up 1% on a y-o-y basis. MetLife's operating earnings for the Retirement and Income Solutions segment totaled $254 million for Q3 2017, down 18% on a y-o-y basis, primarily due to a decline in interest margins, and less favorable underwriting. The segment's operating premiums, fees, and other revenues soared 71% to $2.5 billion, driven by pension risk transfer transactions in the reported quarter. In Q3 2017, MetLife's operating earnings for the Property & Casualty segment were $51 million, down 12% on a y-o-y basis, primarily due to higher catastrophe losses from hurricanes Harvey and Irma. The segment's operating premiums, fees, and other revenues were $899 million, up 2% on a y-o-y basis, while the segment's sales grew 1% to $134 million. For Q3 2017, MetLife's operating earnings for the Asia segment were $314 million, down 3%, and unchanged on a constant currency basis, as volume growth and the actuarial assumption review were offset by a higher 2017 annual Japan tax rate. The segment's operating premiums, fees, and other revenues were $2.2 billion, down 3% on a reported basis, however up 3% on a constant currency basis. MetLife's total sales for the region were $565 million, up 3% on a constant currency basis. During Q3 2017, MetLife's operating earnings for the Latin America segment surged 23% to $163 million, due to a favorable underwriting and volume growth. The segment's operating premiums, fees, and other revenues were $937 million, up 5% on a y-o-y basis. MetLife's operating earnings for Europe, the Middle-East and Africa (EMEA) segment were $71 million, down 4% on a y-o-y basis, and 1% on a constant currency basis, as volume growth and expense margin improvements were offset by a less favorable underwriting and the impact from several non-recurring items. The segment's operating premiums, fees, and other revenues were $634 million, up 2% on a reported basis and constant currency basis. The Company's total sales from the region were $257 million, up 9% on a constant currency basis, driven by a strong growth in the Gulf and Turkey. During Q3 2017, operating earnings for MetLife Holdings were $410 million, up 54% on a y-o-y basis. The segment's operating premiums, fees, and other revenues were $1.4 billion, down 12% on a y-o-y basis, mostly due to separation-related impacts. Share Repurchase and Brighthouse Exchange In a separate press release on the same day, MetLife announced that its Board of Directors had approved a new $2 billion authorization for the Company to repurchase its common stock. In 2016, MetLife announced a $3 billion repurchase program, and the Company has bought back approximately $2.8 billion of its common stock under that board authorization. MetLife also announced that it currently intends to divest its remaining Brighthouse common stock through an exchange offer for MetLife common stock during 2018. The exchange offer would be governed by a separate board authorization, and subject to market conditions and regulatory approval. content: ATLANTA, Nov 20, 2017 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE via COMTEX) -- Atlantic American Corporation AAME, +3.13% today announced that the Board of Directors has appointed J. Ross Franklin to serve as Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, and Corporate Secretary, of the Company. He has been serving as Interim Chief Financial Officer since August 1, 2017. Mr. Franklin has more than 18 years of accounting and financial management experience. Since 2000 he has held various roles of increasing responsibility with Atlantic American and its subsidiaries, serving as Vice President, Accounting and Treasurer of Bankers Fidelity since 2009. He is a Certified Public Accountant and earned both Master of Professional Accounting and Master in Business Administration degrees from Georgia State University. "I couldn't be more thrilled to welcome Ross as the new Chief Financial Officer of Atlantic American," said Hilton H. Howell, Jr., chairman, president and chief executive officer of the Company. "With almost two decades of history with the Company, Ross brings a deep understanding of our business and will undoubtedly be successful in his new role." Atlantic American is an insurance holding company involved through its subsidiary companies in specialty markets of the life, health, and property and casualty insurance industries. Its principal insurance subsidiaries are American Southern Insurance Company, American Safety Insurance Company, Bankers Fidelity Life Insurance Company and Bankers Fidelity Assurance Company. content: ATLANTA, Aug 14, 2017 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE via COMTEX) -- Insurance premiums increased 2.6% and 4.3% for the three month and six month periods ended June 30, 2017, respectively, as compared to the comparable periods of 2016 Net income for the three month and six month periods ended June 30, 2017 was $1.5 million and $1.2 million, respectively, as compared to $0.2 million and $1.1 million, respectively, for the comparable periods of 2016 Atlantic American Corporation AAME, +3.13% today reported net income of $1.5 million, or $0.07 per diluted share, for the three month period ended June 30, 2017, compared to net income of $0.2 million, or $0.01 per diluted share, for the three month period ended June 30, 2016. For the six month period ended June 30, 2017, net income was $1.2 million, or $0.05 per diluted share, compared to net income of $1.1 million, or $0.05 per diluted share, for the comparable period in 2016. Realized investment gains for the three month and six month periods ended June 30, 2017 were $1.4 million and $2.3 million, respectively, as compared to $0.1 million and $0.9 million in the comparable three month and six month periods of 2016. Operating income (income before income taxes and realized investment gains, net) for the three month period ended June 30, 2017 was $0.8 million, as compared to $0.2 million for the three month period ended June 30, 2016. For the six month period ended June 30, 2017, the Company had an operating loss of $0.4 million as compared to operating income of $0.8 million for the comparable six month period of 2016. The operating loss was attributable to higher than expected levels of claims in both life and health lines of business during the first quarter of 2017. Total revenues for the three month period ended June 30, 2017 were $43.6 million, increasing 4.2% from $41.9 million for the three month period ended June 30, 2016. While life and health premiums increased 6.4%, property and casualty premiums decreased 4.6%. For the six month period ended June 30, 2017, total revenues were $87.5 million, increasing 4.7% from the comparable 2016 period. Premiums earned from the Company's life and health operation increased 9.2% for the six month period ended June 30, 2017 while decreasing 4.6% in the property and casualty operation during the comparable period. Commenting on the quarter, Hilton H. Howell, Jr., chairman, president and chief executive officer, noted, "We are pleased that the level of Medicare supplement benefit expenses and life insurance claims returned to historical levels in the second quarter. Our distribution network for the life and health operation continues to perform exceptionally well and we expect another record year in premium growth. In addition, the Worksite division has enjoyed a steady pace of sales activity and we believe they are well positioned going into the second half of the year when open enrollment kicks into high gear. Although premiums in the property and casualty operations were down slightly, they continue to produce strong profits." Atlantic American is an insurance holding company involved through its subsidiary companies in specialty markets of the life, health, and property and casualty insurance industries. Its principal insurance subsidiaries are American Southern Insurance Company, American Safety Insurance Company, Bankers Fidelity Life Insurance Company and Bankers Fidelity Assurance Company. content: ATLANTA, May 12, 2017 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE via COMTEX) -- Atlantic American Corporation AAME, +3.13% today reported a first quarter 2017 net loss of $0.2 million, or $0.02 per common share, as compared to net income of $0.9 million, or $0.04 per common share, in the first quarter of 2016.  Realized investment gains during the first quarter of 2017 were $0.9 million as compared to $0.8 million in the first quarter of 2016.  The net loss was attributable to higher than expected levels of claims in both life and health lines of business.  Most notable were the early season Medicare Supplement Part B deductible reimbursements on new business which have not yet been through an annual earnings cycle.  Total insurance premiums for the quarter ended March 31, 2017 increased 6.0% to $40.8 million as compared to $38.5 million in the first quarter of 2016; while Medicare Supplement premiums increased 14.1% during the comparable period to $23.9 million from $20.9 million.  Total revenues were $43.9 million for the quarter ended March 31, 2017 as compared to $41.7 million for the quarter ended March 31, 2016. Commenting on the quarter, Hilton H. Howell, Jr., chairman, president and chief executive officer, stated, "We continue to move forward with great optimism and confidence in our business strategies.  Our Worksite/Group division was officially launched in the first quarter and is experiencing an encouraging level of sales.  Our Individual division has recently released a new hospital indemnity product that we feel will have high market acceptance.  Diversification of our sales portfolio continues to be a primary focus.  We expect that the increased level of Medicare supplement benefit expenses and life insurance claims we experienced in the first quarter will moderate naturally and historically, thus allowing us to return to expected levels of profitability throughout the remainder of the year.  Our property and casualty operations continue to perform well and we look forward to better quarters in the balance of the year." Atlantic American is an insurance holding company involved through its subsidiary companies in specialty markets of the life, health, and property and casualty insurance industries.  Its principal insurance subsidiaries are American Southern Insurance Company, American Safety Insurance Company, Bankers Fidelity Life Insurance Company and Bankers Fidelity Assurance Company.
